Problem:
Consider a signal processing system where a signal \\( x(t) \\) is transformed by a Fourier Transform, resulting in \\( X(\\omega) \\). To further analyze or manipulate the signal, an operator \\( P(\\omega) \\) is applied in the frequency domain.

If an intervention function \\( Q(\\omega) \\) is applied to \\( P(\\omega)X(\\omega) \\) after \\( X(\\omega) \\) is computed, will the resultant inverse Fourier Transform still purely depend on \\( P(\\omega) \\)?
Explanation: The additional intervention \\( Q(\\omega) \\) modifies \\( X(\\omega) \\) already impacted by \\( P(\\omega) \\), thus the result, when taken inverse Fourier Transform, will depend on both \\( P(\\omega) \\) and \\( Q(\\omega) \\) and not just on \\( P(\\omega) \\).

causal_map_integration: The signal x(t) is transformed by the Fourier Transform to produce X(ω).
